head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL, KUWAIT, DAY

text: One more tug on the sheet and we see, and suddenly hear, William Starks' P.O.V. the CHAOS of the hospital around h as DOCTORS and NURSES tend as best as they can to the inj soldiers. Our glimpse of STARKS reveals a red stretcher -- soaked i and the severe head wound where a bullet's minced his sku Then, slowly, steadily, a heartbeat is heard over the muf sounds of the hospital and, as his pulse quickens, so doe the pace of the world around him.

head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL, KUWAIT, DAY

text: I remember there was so much white everywhere. And I felt peace...even though there was war around me. And I felt alive, even though I knew I was dead.
Come on, come on, let's tag these guys and get them out of here.

An INTERN, clipboard in hand, stands above STARKS' unmovi body with another INTERN (2) beside him. INTERN 1 pulls the rest of the SHEET off of STARKS as the OTHER searches his DOG TAGS and gently closes his EYES with her hand. INTERN #2 [Reading from the TAGS] Starks, William. Born December 25,
Wait, so how old?
[Searching through records] Here he is. William Starks. Born in Vermont. He hasn't got a family listed. The naval hospital'll figure out what to do with him.

As the INTERN puts the TAGS back down, she meets STARKS' open EYES -- now filled with surfacing tears, sadness, an She stares at them curiously and, after some seconds, STA blinks and a TEAR runs down his cheek -- jarring her. INTERN #2 [Calling out] Oh my God! This soldier is ALIVE! Code blue! CODE BLUE! This man just blinked!
He's been tagged already. Worry about the others... [then seeing STARKS blink] Oh shit! Shit! CODE BLUE! We need a doctor! Get a doctor over here now!
As the MEDICAL STAFF rush over to STARKS, preparing NEEDL and OXYGEN MASKS, STARKS merely closes his eyes and we fo the now BLOODIED white sheet as it falls to the ground...

head_text.subj: EXT. IRAQI VILLAGE, DAY

text: A NEWSANCHOR interviews CAPTAIN ROBERT MEDLEY (30s) -- a particularly photogenic and affable participant.
The level of arms on the ground really depends. [Answering a question] But no, I'd have to say we haven't had to engage on the ground as heavily as we might have expected.
Have you lost any men today, Captain?
No. One of my Corporals took a bullet to the head, but it looks like he might make it. Looks that way...

head_text.subj: EXT. IRAQI VILLAGE, DAY

text: We see only the HAND, and not the man to whom it belongs, enter the frame and pull the TRIGGER on a gun. The sound pierces the air, and the bullet hits the side of STARKS' in a FLASH, shaving the skin around it right off.

head_text.subj: EXT. AMERICAN NAVAL HOSPITAL, DAY

text: STARKS convalesces in a navy hospital bed -- his head hea BANDAGED and his arms suited with I.V.'s and dressings -- MAJOR, a LIEUTENANT and a DOCTOR stand above him. STARKS' face -- now cleaned of the blood that masked it b is alert, and striking. Even with the bandages, he remain well-built and strong, like a shot straight to the head w have been the only way for an enemy to take him down.
Sergeant Starks was very lucky. A little more to the right and it wouldn't have wanted to come out...
But he's never gonna be able to remember what happened?

It's hard to say. Sergeant Starks could have retrograde amnesia or... [lowering his voice] any form of psychological suppression. It's very common with traumas like this. STARKS [Cutting him off] Sergeant Starks is in the room, [beat] and I want to know when I'm going home.
When he speaks, STARKS maintains the sharp, steady gaze o man assured of himself, even if he is lost among his surroundings.
Sergeant, you have no surviving family in the States. I'm sure you have friends or distant relatives, but unfortunately we have no record of them yet.
Captain Medley has recommended you for the Purple Heart, Sergeant.
STARKS lets the tribute roll right off him. He spots the CIGARETTES in the Lieutenant's pocket.
Can I have one of those?
Of course.
The LIEUTENANT lights one for him.
There is help for you, Sergeant.
Of course there is.
Their VOICES start to fade as STARKS smokes his cigarette blowing the SMOKE upwards and following it with his eyes. He's finished with these men and everything they stand fo
I didn't know where my home was. I just knew I didn't want to be there anymore.

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGHWAY, RURAL VERMONT, WINTER, DAY

text: STARKS -- recovered now -- walks by himself along a long highway. He seems to be walking away from things even if can't remember what they are yet.

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGHWAY, RURAL VERMONT, WINTER, DAY

text: JEAN PRICE (30s) -- a hippie who happens to be a mother - her daughter, JACKIE (8) tremble in the cold next to thei stalled car. JEAN sits next to the car, holding her knees her chest, more like a child than her daughter. JACKIE runs her little gloved hand over her mom's ski-hat head as she cautiously watches STARKS approach them. He c an arresting figure against the empty landscape.
Come on, mom. Don't fall asleep...
You two ok?
Our car won't start.
STARKS [Looking at JEAN] What's your mom's name? JACKIE [Cautiously] Jean.
STARKS takes off his backpack and kneels down.
Jean? Jean, can you hear me? I need you to try to wake up, Jean.
JEAN opens her eyes, stone red.
Your mom take anything before this happened?
Yeah, but I don't know what.
[Beat] What's your name?
Jackie.
JACKIE decidedly sticks out her gloved hand. STARKS smile and briefly shakes it. STARKS rubs a hand over his chin a cheek as he thinks of what to do.
Nice to meet you, Jackie. Why don't you wrap this scarf around yourself and try to keep your mom awake while I take a look at your car.

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGHWAY, RURAL VERMONT, WINTER, DAY

text: As Starks works on their engine, JACKIE anxiously watches mother throw up in the distance. STARKS sees her watching tries to distract her.
What do you think of all this snow?
JACKIE looks at him curiously.
[Beat] Nothing.
STARKS looks at her and smiles at her honest answer; Jack turns her head back towards her mother.
But I like it I guess.
Hey, can you reach the gas pedal?
Yeah.
JACKIE gets behind the wheel, crouching down in the seat enough so her foot reaches the pedal.
Go ahead, turn it on. Keep pushing it.
JACKIE revs up the engine and, a few coughs and sputters later, the car settles into a nice, working hum. JACKIE [Smiling] It works!
JACKIE steps down. She looks like she could hug Starks an unexpectedly, decides to. As STARKS awkwardly returns it, sees JEAN lifting her eyes to see him holding her daughte
Get your fucking hands off my daughter!
Mom, he just fixed our car.
Jackie, get in the car. NOW!
JEAN reaches for a RIFLE in the back of the truck but stumbles from the nausea before she can pick it up.
Look, I don't want any trouble, so...
Neither do I, ma'am. I'll be on my way.
Mom, you've got it wrong...
STARKS motions for JACKIE to stop as he collects his bags
You're just gonna walk?
Yeah, I'll hitch a ride or something. [Beat] Let her throw it all up before she gets back behind the wheel.
STARKS' DOG TAGS are tied to the ZIPPER of one of his bag
What're those?
Dog tags. [Off her blank look] They've got your name and date of birth for identification.
What for?
[Beat] In case you get lost, or can't remember who you are. Hm.
STARKS unties them and gives them to her. She reads them.
I think I can remember what's on them.
William Starks. [Beat] Thanks.
STARKS faces the screen with nothing but a cryptic BLACKN about him and a confused look on his face as a MENACING V questions him.
"Jackie" and "Jean" are the only ...things you know for certain about that day?
STARKS nods.
Are you aware we have no last name, no place of residence, and no record of any physical presence for these "friends" of yours? How's that possible in this day and age?
STARKS nods as a muffled "Objection" flickers away in the background...
I may need to actually hear that answer, Mr. Starks.
[Beat] Yes.

With Starks' answer, the background of the courtroom is suddenly illuminated and we see that THIS IS STARKS' OWN TRIAL. The VOICE belongs to a satisfied PROSECUTION who t to face a medium-sized CROWD watching on...

There are three KEY WITNESSES called to the stand: CAPTAI MEDLEY, Starks' commanding officer in the Persian Gulf; D HALE, a psychiatrist; and OFFICER NASH, the cop who first came upon the crime scene. Their three testimonies are intercut to present the case against Starks quickly and confusingly -- just like it appears to himself. OFFICER NASH [Emotional] Eddie [correcting himself], Officer Harrison, was lying in a pool of his own blood -- on his back.

William Starks could be blocking the incident. It would explain his well- systematized scheme about the little girl and her mother. A delusion as complex as that can often replace the reality of an incident like this. OFFICER NASH [Cont'd] Officer Harrison'd been shot three times. He was long dead by the time we got there.
I have heard of Gulf War Syndrome. The medical community is only beginning to gather information about it.
Gulf War   Syndrome? What the...Why don't we   start diagnosing Hard Life Syndrome   while we're at it? I've gotten a   lot of convictions we could overturn   with that logic...

Sergeant Starks was awarded the Purple Heart. That award doesn't applaud violence or murder. [Beat] It applauds honor. DR. HALE [Cont'd] His subconscious is blocking it, the same way it began to in the Gulf, particularly as something similarly traumatizing happened to him then.

The following summations are punctuated by the BLACK FADE between them and the simulated BLACK around them as they speak -- like STARKS, at the beginning of his own testimo PROSECUTION [Disdainfully] It's not a question of whether or not he was sane when he did it?! He absolutely was. Three bullets in one man are three moral failings in another. CAPTAIN MEDLEY [Incensed] War isn't a CNN Special. Half the shit that went on couldn't be tidied into a top of the hour headline -- either 'cause it couldn't be said neatly or 'cause it couldn't be said at all. It was ugly. And they don't put ugly on TV. [Looking at Starks] If Starks did kill that officer ... [Beat] You can't hold a man responsible for a damaged mind.
For God's sake, my client said he thinks he's already died once. He doesn't know what's going on.

head_text.subj: EXT. MURDER SCENE, HIGHWAY, VERMONT, DUSK

text: STARKS lies bleeding -- eyes half open -- by OFFICER HARR dead, bloodied body as falling SNOW slowly whitens them b and covers any FOOTPRINTS that may have been left behind. hear a distant gavel delivering a distant judgment... STARKS [V.O., nearly whispered] I don't know how it happened.
STARKS' eyes finally close as he lapses into unconsciousn
The JUDGE nods as he hands the JURY FOREMAN back the verd
On the count of first degree murder, we find the defendant, William Starks, not guilty by reason of insanity.

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGHWAY, RURAL VERMONT, WINTER, DAY

text: In his mind, STARKS is walking out of the woods as the su sets and bounces off the snow all around him. We see JACK watching him walk away into the woods.
I hereby sentence you to be committed to a facility for the criminally insane, where I hope that doctors and the proper treatment can help you...
The JUDGE sentences STARKS, who stares back vacantly, lik man who checked out of his life long before this judge decided he had to.

head_text.subj: EXT. ALPINE GROVE PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL, DAY

text: A white VAN pulls up to Alpine Grove Psychiatric Hospital bleak, dated facility embellished only by the barbed wire that seems to be everywhere around it.
STARKS' anatomy instantly and intensely separates him fro the staff of the hospital and the infirm patients who mig be in it. TWO MEMBERS of that STAFF lead him in.
Mr. Starks, I hope that someday you might be well so that we will have lost only one life in this tragedy.

location: CONFERENCE ROOM, ALPINE GROVE MENTAL HOSPITAL

text: DR. THOMAS BECKER (overworked, dogmatic, disenchanted), D BETH LORENSON (30s, unassuming, perceptive), and DR. GRIE (20s, green) are convened with other STAFF at a routine hospital meeting. These doctors deal in the currency of madness every day and wear the heaviness of that burden o their faces.
I'd certainly say he should be considered violent, just given his case...
How'd he dodge a conviction?
His defense argued post-traumatic stress and delusional disorder. He evidently couldn't account for a similar incident during his service in Desert Storm.
[Beat] So why isn't he just in the psych ward of the county jail?
Apparently, he's a decorated vet. And had another one testify for him. Who knows? [To DR. BECKER] Tom, do you mind taking him?
BECKER shrugs a nod as the Chief moves on to the next ord of business...

head_text.subj: INT. STARKS' ROOM, WARD, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: STARKS is shown to his room by NURSE HARDING -- stern, se and her henchman, DAMON -- a BURLY ORDERLY who relishes h command, however diluted it may be. DAMON unceremoniously puts Starks' UNIFORM on the bed. He NURSE HARDING wait at the door for Starks to change into

DAMON looks at STARKS -- his eyes inadvertently conceding Starks is more threatening than the common senile he marshals; STARKS stares him back -- deliberately concedin that he's right. STARKS turns around -- only then looking stunned in the sterile, cotton-white room, wondering where his life disappeared to.

head_text.subj: INT. DR. BECKER'S OFFICE, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: STARKS sits opposite DR. BECKER in a harsh, tiled office. STARKS wears his blue uniform and BECKER wears a doubtful expression. From STARKS' P.O.V.: the DRUGS they've alread started giving him BLUR his vision of Becker.
William? William, can you hear me?
STARKS nods groggily.
I've given you some drugs to help with your adjustment... STARKS [Cutting him off] What kind of drugs? [Beat] 'Cause these seem pretty...pretty serious.
Well, your condition's pretty serious.
[Beat] So they say. [Off Becker's steady gaze] What?
I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?
Depends on what you're seeing.
BECKER eyes STARKS mistrustfully.
You said you couldn't remember killing Officer Harrison. Correct?
[Beat] You don't believe me, do you?

It's not my job to believe you. STARKS [Squinting to better see] You're a doctor. I would think... BECKER [Cutting him off firmly] It's not my job to believe you or to understand you. It's my job to try to cure you and if that's a no-go, then to...take some kind of care of you. STARKS [Flatly] Lucky me.

BECKER looks at Starks -- his eyes casting shame upon the alleged murderer that sits before him. BECKER [Stupefied] You shot a man three times: first in his heart, then in his stomach and then...point blank, in the back of his head. And then you just...forgot all about it. A whole life erased with three easy little words: I. Don't. Know. What would it be if we could all not know what we didn't want to have to face.
BECKER glances at his WATCH and gets up -- still blurred Starks' P.O.V. It's only as he's walking off that Starks notices he has a limp.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: From STARKS' P.O.V., we follow him walk down the hospital halls, even hazier from the medication than before. FORMS blur into one another and, on either side of him is a cra world with crazy patients who've lost their way in it. STARKS reaches for the WALL and runs his HAND over it, tr to keep his balance. He's walking towards BECKER who stan at the end of the hall, talking to other PATIENTS. STARKS [Softly] I don't belong here. I don't...

STARKS falters but stays up. He turns to see a shell of a OLD MAN looking right through him with wooden eyes. STARK eyes stay so completely fixed on the old man's haunting s that he doesn't see what's ahead of him.
He bumps right into a HYSTERICAL PATIENT whose sudden, earsplitting SCREAMS peal interminably through the air. STARKS [Mumbling] I'm sorry. I didn't mean... I'm sorry. I didn't mean it.

STARKS' fumbled efforts to help the PATIENT only feed his hysteria more. The SCREAMING is intolerable. STARKS [Forced to yell] Will you listen to me? I'm not going to hurt you. Please. I didn't mean to bump...I'm sorry.
ORDERLIES and NURSES, followed by DR. BECKER, surround th now, violently pulling STARKS off the patient. BECKER, familiar with the PATIENT (HAROLD), tries to calm him.
It's ok, Harold. It's ok.
STARKS searches their blurred faces and stops on Becker's they restrain him and give him more drugs. STARKS [To Becker] I don't belong here... BECKER [Angrily, to the ORDERLIES] Get him to his room.

head_text.subj: INT. STARKS' ROOM, ALPINE GROVE, LATE NIGHT

text: STARKS is slowly rebounding from the drugs when he hears disquieting FOOTSTEPS in the hall, coming closer and closer... What follows happens too quickly for STARKS to react. DR. GRIES, NURSE HARDING AND DAMON -- enter Starks' room. They close the door and deftly administer a TRANQUILIZER a GAG. STARKS has no idea what's happening to him as they drag h out, and his STIFLED CRIES ensure no one else does either
Come on, army boy. Time for some therapy.

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, BASEMENT, ALPINE GROVE, LATE NIGHT

text: The first face STARKS sees as the world comes into focus NURSE HARDING'S. Around it loom those of DR. BECKER, DR. GRIES and DAMON. A shot of the room shows a constraint-ridden apparatus hanging sternly on the wall. It is THE JACKET: an apparat designed to encase a man's body. Made of coarse, sickly- stained red ands brown canvas and velcro restraints that first chafe, then forever burn, the skin they're wrapped around, the JACKET looks medieval. Its appearance suggest its purpose: to slowly STRANGLE THE LIFE OUT OF A MAN. STARKS has been stripped of his blue uniform and is lying nearly naked on a burial slab in the cold of the basement Even under the tranquilizers, STARKS formidably resists t as the ORDERLIES wrestle to strap him in. Then Starks, sensing as anyone would, that something bad is being done him, wisely stops resisting long enough to petition them.
Wait. Wait a minute... Please.
BECKER motions for them to stop with his hand. STARKS bli trying to bring the faces above him into focus...
I, I don't belong here.
BECKER looks into Starks' eyes. Sanity stares back.
No. I don't think you do either. [Beat] But neither of us can do anything about that.

BECKER barely nods and STARKS is trussed in the JACKET wi METAL CLAMPS. BECKER writes some details down, presumably about Starks' treatment. A CADAVER DRAWER -- just barely deep enough for a body or enough for the height of a nose -- is slid open and STARK already dreadfully sheathed in the JACKET, is crammed ins The ORDERLIES slam the cadaver drawer into the wall.

STARKS is literally entombed alive. Silence. Stolen breat They bolt the drawer and the CLANG echoes through his bod The BLACKNESS and CLOSENESS of the space choke him as his heart beats the frantic rhythm of his struggle.

We see only the WHITES of a pair of petrified EYES on a m who's losing it -- hyperventilating, suffocating... for a intents and purposes, dying the worst kind of a death. Combing the walls for any sign of an explanation of what' happening to him, STARKS sees a single white DOT -- almos like a fleck of dust -- flitting between undecided SHAPES the blackness until, slowly, it grows bigger and bigger..

It's now a PATTERN of WHITE DOTS that changes the more ST stares at it. Beneath it seems to be a smaller pattern wi formless shapes and figures that STARKS tries to discern before they change into something else. Only after STARKS blinks does he start to see the WHITE of the DOTS is SNOW from a picture that is slowly and terribly coming togethe the following glimpses, each hardly longer than the time between BLINKS. 1) A little river of RED marring the snow around it, spilling from... 2) OFFICER HARRISON'S mouth just seconds before his last breath. His eyes close and STARKS sees and hears a FLASH. 3) From the barrel of a GUN fired near him. BLOOD sprays STARKS' hands as he looks down at them and realizes he's in the scene and not just watching it. He l up from his hands and sees in similar flashes... 1) The snow beneath the BLOOD changing to DIRT as STARKS stares at it. This time, the little river of RED comes from... 2) The BODIES of IRAQI villagers, all still except one... 3) That of a IRAQI WOMAN. She unflinchingly lays her hand in the entrails of a CORPSE and smears its blood on her face just before she lies back down among the dead, content to be one of them. The only SOUNDS during these dreadful images have been a trapped man's anxious BREATHS and the BEATS of a HEART pumping so fast it could be a drum... The screen goes BLACK and QUIVERS as STARKS clenches his shut.

Just then, as the MUSCLE beneath his eyes starts to VIBRA something terrible and wet falls from the ceiling of the drawer. PING! Right on his eye. The drop of WATER is enou to send this man right over the edge. STARKS' EYES roll back into his head and start to flutter shaking the SCREEN right along them until...

STARKS stands outside his body, looking at the wall of drawers he is in. He bends down to look more closely at a STAIN on the floor -- DRIED BLOOD -- and as he runs his H it and stands back up, he is back in the...
IMAGES RACE PAST HIM too fast for him to catch anything b fleeting clips of them. The IMAGES are his MEMORY and, no matter how badly he wants to slow them down, he can't...

STARKS sees JACKIE, 8, sitting by a window in the diner. turns her head towards the ENTRANCE and, as she looks the so does Starks. That is when he first lays eyes on a woma WAITRESS -- worn but still lovely -- leaving the diner. H taken with her and, for the first time since he's been in Jacket, seems calm. Just then, however, the reverie is shattered...

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, BASEMENT, ALPINE GROVE, LATE NIGHT

text: The drawer is yanked open to reveal STARKS' still, drench face. BECKER, GRIES and the ORDERLIES stand above him.
Take him out of it.
The ORDERLIES unstrap the JACKET from his body. Blood fro his chafed skin drips onto the burial slab. STARKS' eyes remain closed.
William. William, can you hear me?

We hear BECKER's voice as it sounds to STARKS...MUTED. STARKS' EYES open only enough for him to see the PEOPLE'S FACES morph chillingly into one another's. DR. GRIES [Less muffled] Pulse is 16, temp, just a hair under 90. 'Bout right for three hours of psychosis.
That's not enough, is it?
BECKER looks at STARKS' battered body. BECKER [Wearily, indifferently] It's enough for now. Take him to the infirmary and let him recover there.

head_text.subj: INT. WARD, ALPINE GROVE, NEXT MORNING

text: STARKS sits, totally disoriented, in the ward with the ot more vocally INSANE patients. He runs his hand uncertainl over the SCARS on his arm from the Jacket and looks aroun not knowing where his PARANOIA ends and REALITY begins. The OLD MAN from the previous day is moving slowly with t aid of his walker. He is far less threatening to STARKS today...just a senile man about to walk into a wall. STARKS [Getting up to help him] Let's get you a destination other than this wall.
RUDY MACKENZIE -- 40s, smart eyes, fidgety, with an innoc face -- watches STARKS help turn the OLD MAN around.

That's Kingsley. Old bastard hears us, I'm sure. He just doesn't want to bother answering so he makes us think he can't talk. I know. I tried it on my mother for two months once before she fished out my tongue. Literally. [Beat] You're the cop killer, right?
Yeah, guess so. How'd you know?
TV. Helps numb [makes a "crazy gesture"] any active mind. [Sticking out a jittery hand] Rudy MacKenzie.
MACKENZIE (cont'd) Welcome to the village, William Starks.
STARKS doesn't offer his hand, just looks back at MacKenz STARKS [Looking away] I'm not really in the mood to talk.

That's too bad. I don't believe in disposable language either -- you know, the small talk, the little talk. Chit. Chat. Useless. The game's something else though. Think about it: What can we trade with each other in the air between us? This... [running his hand through the air] is our court. [Beat, so eager it's sad] I'm ready to throw the ball. Come on.

STARKS looks at MACKENZIE and sees that the constant flow words from his mouth only masks the tragic hesitation in eyes. A dead arm hangs limply by his side, like a weight. STARKS [Relenting] What are you in here for?
I tried to kill my wife.
Don't you go to jail for that?
I tried something like 30 times.
There is, as STARKS rightly figures, no suitable response that.

She's bigger than me, and she's stronger than me. And I never planned on doing it. It was always in the heat of the moment. I didn't beat her or anything. Hell, she beat me. But when we'd start fighting, I'd go for the knife. Then she kept threatening to have me put away, and [looking around] she finally did.
As he talks, MACKENZIE notes the SCARS on Starks' arms. D LORENSON observes STARKS and MACKENZIE talking and starts walking towards them.
Yeah, well 30 times probably would make you seem crazy.
Or just plain stupid. You'd think by the twentieth time, I'd have found an alternative method. Maybe a more effective one, if you know what I mean.
Morning, gentlemen. How are you doing today?
MACKENZIE winks discreetly at STARKS before he replies.

It's a hard one for me, Dr. Lorenson. [Finally turns to face her, grimly] The world around me, it's shrinking. There's not even room for light to make its way in. [Beat] Da-da-bum! Da- da-bum! I feel like the horseman of doom is coming for me, Doc. Only today, he's not carrying flowers.
LORENSON reprimands MacKenzie by turning to Starks.
What? It's better than fine.
And you, Mr. Starks? STARKS [Already on the defense] I'm fine.
Mr. MacKenzie, do you think I could talk to Mr. Starks privately?
Of course you can, Doc. William, it was an absolute pleasure. Thanks for playing.
Just before he walks away, MACKENZIE turns around nervous and uncharacteristically looks STARKS right in the eye.
Hey...when they talk you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them. [Beat] They don't eat you when there's music playing.
STARKS looks at MacKenzie briskly, wondering if his words were directed or just the meandering of a nut. But MacKen just nods his farewell and starts humming as he walks awa dead arm in tow.
So you're ok? STARKS [Still distracted] What?
I asked you if you're ok. STARKS [Suspiciously] I don't know. You tell me, Doc. You think there's anything wrong with me?
I don't know. You're not my patient.
STARKS looks away. Lorenson gives him a once over.
You look like you've lost some weight. Are you eating?
I am. One of the few things I remember doing is eating. So I guess I must be exercising it off in my dreams.
STARKS looks at LORENSON, seeing if he'll respond. LORENS looks back curiously at STARKS' pointed stare.
You done with your small talk?
Sure.
Good.
STARKS walks away slowly and WEAKLY -- a fact that doesn' escape LORENSON's observation.

head_text.subj: INT. MEN'S ROOM, ALPINE GROVE HOSPITAL, DAY

text: STARKS walks into the bathroom, keenly eyeing the thin sl of WINDOWS at the top of the wall. He walks closer to the when he suddenly hears some STRAINED BREATHING from insid one of the stalls. He checks the first stall, pushing it open. It swings both ways since it doesn't have a lock. The sound continues. STARKS walks slowly past the second stall to the third and then... WHACK! The door swings all way towards STARKS. BRUTALLY. He falls backwards -- his h just barely missing a fatal confrontation with the sink. DAMON, the ORDERLY, walks out.
I'm sorry, Starks. Must have not seen you coming there.
STARKS writhes in PAIN -- straining for his own breath no DAMON [Leaning down close to him] Were you worried about me? [Smiling] That's so sweet. Thanks.
With that, DAMON walks out, leaving STARKS on the floor.

head_text.subj: INT. STARKS' ROOM, ALPINE GROVE, NIGHT, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: STARKS sits in his room, listening to the silence of the night interrupted by first faint, then approaching, FOOTSTEPS. Closer and closer...then harmfully near until DAMON and HARDING enter his room. They pause -- awaiting a reaction. STARKS doesn't give th one.
You gonna get the fuck up?

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, ALPINE GROVE, NIGHT, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: STARKS walks stoically down the cold corridors to his own torture -- flanked by HARDING and DAMON on either side.

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, BASEMENT, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: They're all in the room. STARKS seems pretty calm. Only i C.U. do we see his eyes register the JACKET...
I'm glad to see you're cooperating this time, Mr. Starks.

STARKS looks at the WIDE, STURDY restraints on it. They w really hurt if you hit someone as hard as you could with them. They might even knock someone out... DAMON and HARDING move to undress him, when STARKS makes move to do it himself. They look to DR. BECKER who NODS t it's all right. DAMON begrudgingly lets go of Starks but not before he st on one of Starks' bare feet. STARKS doesn't flinch. He merely turns away from them and bends down to take off his pants. On his way up, he GRABS JACKET OFF ITS HOOK and, using it like a weapon, aims to smack it across Damon's face. DAMON deftly ducks and the JACKET hits BECKER instead. The force of the blow sends Becker down, and as he falls against the wall, DAMON and HARDING leap to restrain Starks. BECKER   opens and closes his eyes, trying to get them in focus.   His right cheek is cut pretty bad. DR. GRIES hel BECKER   to his feet and picks his BROKEN GLASSES up off floor.   BECKER puts them on.
Hold him while I get the tranquilizer.
Fuck the tranquilizer! I got a foot.
DAMON KICKS Starks hard in the back, nearly sending him d
No. That's not necessary.
BECKER looks down and sees his own BLOOD fall on the floo He looks up at STARKS who, even in his pain, looks shocke the force he just used.
Let him go. [More firmly] I said, let him go!

As soon as they let him go, STARKS lunges for BECKER -- pushing him up against the wall. STARKS stops, presumably about to harm Becker but unsure, even to himself, of what he's capable of doing... BECKER looks fearlessly into Starks' eyes.
BECKER [An inch away from his face] What, Starks? What are you going to do? End me just because I'm an inconvenience to you? [Beat] Just like you did with Officer Harrison?
STARKS' face registers the meaning in Becker's words and look of self-doubt crosses his face.
The only thing your mind is missing is a conscience.
STARKS lets go of him and, as soon as he does, DAMON and HARDING restrain him. BECKER calmly wipes the BLOOD from face, looks at his hand, shakes his head and walks out.
Wait...Dr. Becker, how long do you want us to leave him in for?
BECKER doesn't answer. He doesn't even turn around. DR. G goes after him.
Just strap him in for now.
And DAMON and HARDING start to...

location: BECKER'S OFFICE, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS EVE, SOME T

head_text.subj: LATER

text: BECKER turns around from the window and we see that his c is BANDAGED. He opens a drawer, takes out some SCOTCH and pours himself a SHOT. He swallows some pills with it. After he drinks it, he looks up to see GRIES standing opposite him, watching.
You ok?
I'm fine.
[Beat] Listen, I hate to bother you...
Then don't.
But... what about Starks?
What about Starks?
Should we be...
Should we be what? Trying to change him any way we can? [Beat] Yes.

But the Jacket? I mean...should we be leaving him in like that? BECKER [As if stunned by the question] Leaving him in? [Beat] The medication I'm given him is intended to adjust -- maybe even reset -- his violent proclivities. You know, peel away some of those layers of hate. The Jacket's merely a safe place for that to happen. The grounds and the halls -- where I can't monitor side effects I can't predict -- aren't. DR. GRIES [Still doubtful] But, but...what about... BECKER [Mocking Gries] But...but what about the gun? I mean, should he have been firing away like that? [Shaking his head at GRIES] You can't fuck up a life that's already been fucked up. [Turning away] There, there's the insurance you're looking for.
I'm not looking for anything.
BECKER shakes his head, laughing inside at the world's stupidity.
[Beat] It's Christmas Eve, Justin. Don't you have somewhere to be?
BECKER doesn't wait for an answer, just turns back toward the window and takes another sip of his drink.

head_text.subj: INT. HOSPITAL LOUNGE, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: NURSE HARDING turns on the television as DAMON sits in on the lounge chairs.
Ah, man, look, It's A Wonderful Life.
You got any booze?
HARDING takes out a FLASK from her BACKPACK.
'Course I do. [Smiling] And it is the season for giving so let's get to it.
DAMON smiles and rubs his hands together eagerly.

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, BASEMENT, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: A shot of the WALL OF DRAWERS, with no one in the room, j someone in the wall...

STARKS finds himself in the physically wrenching place on more. But nothing happens for some seconds. He breathes anxiously, not knowing what to expect. His heart beats steadily: THUMP...THUMP, until, finally, with each beat, SMALL WHITE FLECK becomes two flecks...then, two dots...then, two circles...then, the WHITES of a pair of EYES with a terrific meanness in them. The EYES blink, then disappear like they were never there The pace of STARKS' heart quickens, and the inexplicable madness surrounds him once more...

head_text.subj: EXT. MURDER SCENE, HIGHWAY, VERMONT, DUSK

text: The SOUNDS of BOMBS RAGE around him but he's in the middl the murder scene, watching OFFICER HARRISON lie on the fl He turns to look over his shoulder and sees...

head_text.subj: EXT. IRAQI VILLAGE, NIGHT

text: Through a PHOSPHORESCENT GREEN NIGHT-VISION CAMERA, we se FLESH, and RUIN littering the sand. Slowly the terrifying images shift to a naturalistic, real-time documentation of the action -- the ruin -- as it's occurr As STARKS blinks, TEARS fall and he hears, over it all, a counseling voice...
When they take you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them.
The TERRIBLE SOUNDS become less terrible as they fade awa
They don't eat you when there's music playing.
The scene morphs slowly and the following IMAGES appear vaguely -- forming the walls of the TUNNEL around him. 1) C.U. A WOMAN'S NECK and a small child's HAND
3) C.U. A black and white PHOTOGRAPH 4) EXT. CREEK: A shot of clear water, not too deep...

6) EXT. DESERT, IRAQ: A sublime sunset... STARKS walks up uneasily to the wall and touches the IMAG They move like they're liquid and, when they settle, the whole wall is replaced with one large IMAGE of a BEAUTIFU WOMAN -- a waitress -- standing at the counter of a COFFE SHOP, moving a STRAND OF HAIR out of her face with her ha STARKS blinks slowly -- struck by this dream of her. He r out and closes his PALM around her like he might catch ho of the moment with this simple gesture. The whole WALL OF IMAGES twinkles marvelously, as we...

head_text.subj: EXT. DINER, SMALL TOWN, VERMONT, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: The WAITRESS (early 20s) -- tired, with kind eyes, soft s and a beautiful mouth that hasn't smiled in a long time - emerges from the diner. Even with no effort, she is remarkably pretty. From her UNIFORM, we know that her day was spent there. STARKS simply stares at this WOMAN who seems markedly rem from the world around her. The only fact she wears on her that she's tired. She spots STARKS and can't help but do a double-take. Bot are momentarily taken with each other, though she tries t hide any indication that she is.
She gets in her old car and starts it. As it warms up, sh looks for STARKS in her REARVIEW MIRROR and sees he's sti there. He starts to walk over to her when she jumps out of her c

head_text.subj: EXT. PARKING LOT, DINER, VERMONT, CHRISTMAS EVE

text: The WAITRESS treads angrily towards STARKS.
Where do you think you're going?
STARKS looks at her. He doesn't know anymore than she doe
You gonna answer me?
STARKS just stares.
If you're deaf, read my lips...I don't need a psycho following me today.
[Beat] I'm not deaf.
Good.
She turns and gets back in her car, slamming the door shu She starts to drive and STARKS stares after her.
After a few hundred yards, she SLAMS on the brakes and tu the car round, coming back. Then she jumps out of the car heads back in the diner, without looking over at STARKS.

head_text.subj: EXT. DINER, SMALL TOWN VERMONT, SOME SECONDS LATER

text: She comes out -- this time PURSE in hand -- and sighs at Starks.
[As if she owes him an explanation] I forgot my purse.

STARKS nods slowly. The WAITRESS gets in her car and look again at STARKS in her REARVIEW MIRROR. He has hardly any winter gear on him -- no gloves, no hat, no coat -- just and a flannel. He looks lost among his surroundings, as m because he doesn't know where he is as because he doesn't look like he belongs there. She reverses towards him.
In case you hadn't figured, it's Christmas Eve. You're never gonna get a cab here.
[Beat] Thanks.
She looks him over and then rests her hands on the wheel.
All right. [Beat] You got somewhere you need to go, Mister?
I'm not sure.
Let me ask you that again. This time, look around and consider your options.
Being cold and freezing are his options.
[Beat] You got somewhere you need to go, Mister? STARKS [Nodding slowly] Yeah, I do.
Great, get in.
So, where do you want me to drop you?
STARKS rubs his hand over his chin and cheek as he thinks over. She watches him curiously.
I'm not sure.
You don't have anywhere to stay?
I don't think so.
The WAITRESS takes out a FLASK and a sizable SWIG from it she swallows it smoothly, like someone used to doing so.
Well, where are you from?
I'm not sure. [Beat] I don't really know.
Of course you don't know.
Why "of course"?

Because in my life, it wouldn't make sense for me to pick up some normal guy with a place where he's from and a place where he's going to. It'd be too simple. I probably wouldn't know how to handle a situation like that.
Well, you definitely didn't pick normal or simple this time either.
She looks over at him -- momentarily suspicious. He looks innocuously; there's something innately safe about him.
At least you're honest. That's some kind of start.
STARKS sees her take another DRINK from the flask. She pu out a CIGARETTE, and STARKS lights it for her with some MATCHES.
That's great. You're not sure where you're from or where you're going, but at least you've got manners.
She laughs, noticeably more relaxed now after the drink.
Well, you got a coat or something? STARKS [Looking down at his clothes] No. Doesn't look like it.
Well, how'd you get here?
[Beat] I was dropped off.
Do you have a motel or something? Money?
STARKS feels his pockets.
No.
Well, don't you somewhere? Stuff? Belongings?
No. [Beat] Not around here.
She casts a long sideward glance at STARKS, taking him an her circumstances in for herself. He looks back gently.
All right, we'll get to my place and call around, see where I can take you. [Beat] Just don't think of trying anything.
WAITRESS (cont'd) I have the biggest defense for gun control living upstairs from me. She's armed and angry even when she's asleep.

head_text.subj: INT. WAITRESS' APARTMENT, EVENING

text: She is on the PHONE, calling various shelters.   Her apar has some pieces of mismatched furniture, along   with a s of lopsided CHRISTMAS LIGHTS strewn around the   WINDOWS room. They, more than anything else, light the   place. WAITRESS [Pleading tone] I could have him there in 15 minutes. [Beat, disappointed] Hmm. Yeah, thanks. Merry Christmas to you, too.
She hangs up the phone.
Great. That was our last option. What am I going to do with you?
Nothing. [Getting up] Thanks for bringing me this far.
Where are you going? You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat.
I'll manage.
No, you won't. You'll die of cold out there and then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with. [Beat] Do you want something to drink?
No, I'm ok.

She leaves to the KITCHEN to fix herself a drink and STAR stares after her. Suddenly, a SMASHING SOUND is heard as something falls in the kitchen. STARKS' whole BODY TENSES as he wonders whether he's being taken out of the Jacket.
Shit! That was one of my good glasses!

As she presumably cleans it up, we stay on STARKS who slo gains hold of himself. She comes back, DRINK in hand and pushes the STRAND OF HAIR in her face back the same way s did when he saw her in the tunnel. Even through her weariness, she looks radiant under the Christmas lights. takes a long SIP. WAITRESS [Noticing he's shaken] Hey, you ok?
[Beat] Yeah, I'm fine.
You know what? It's Christmas Eve. And you look clean -- I mean, you're normal-looking. [Resolutely, for her own benefit] It's Christmas Eve, and I have a couch.
And sadly, no plans for the evening anyway. She looks bac her EYES even more tired from the liquor.

I'm not gonna hurt you. WAITRESS [Softly] I know. [Clearing her throat] I'm gonna go take a bath. Make yourself at home. You know, fix yourself something to eat if you're hungry or anything. There's nothing to steal, but don't be a jerk and take something anyway. And don't snoop, ok?

Ok. [Beat] My name's William by the way. WAITRESS [Shakes her head] No, no. Let's not do the name stuff, 'cause you see, I don't want to meet you. I may want to help you tonight, but I don't want to know you. Honest.
STARKS nods as she walks out.

head_text.subj: EXT. YARD BEHIND WAITRESS' APARTMENT, EVENING

text: STARKS, still without a coat, collects some WOOD...

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, EVENING

text: STARKS looks in her fridge. There's not much to work with just some JARS and plenty of VODKA.

head_text.subj: INT. LIVING ROOM, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, SOME TIME LATER

text: STARKS has lit a FIRE and set out a feeble dinner for the when the WAITRESS comes out of the bedroom in sweats.
What's this?
The best I could do with what was in your fridge.

She looks and sees a SANDWICH on a BUN in one plate and a SANDWICH on two different colors of TOAST on the other. Then she looks over at the fire; it's obvious from the wa she looks at it that it's been years, if ever, since someone's done something like this for her.
I only lit it because it was so cold in here. I'm sorry if...
No, it's fine. [Beat, swallow] Thanks.
She turns and goes in the kitchen, calling out to him...
You want a drink?
Sure.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, NIGHT

text: As she makes their DRINKS, a curious LOOK crosses her fac just for a second.

location: LIVING ROOM, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, A LITTLE WHILE LAT

text: They've sat down to eat under the blinking CHRISTMAS LIGH
This is pretty good. Considering...
Thanks.
They eat quietly for a second. STARKS looks at her, then at his food, still subtly stunned by it all.
So you're a waitress, right? I mean...from the uniform you were wearing.
Yup. That's me.
You like it?
[Beat] I do it.
Have you always been a waitress? WAITRESS [Remembering sadly] No. I used to be a nurse.
[Beat] Why'd you stop?
Shit happens, and your life changes. 'Bout the best explanation of a lot of things that happen. [Beat] So how come you don't know where you're coming from?
I don't know, but I think part of it's...
STARKS looks around as he decides to be honest with her.
That I don't really know what's real.
She stares at him until a small sympathetic smile appears her lips.
Well, good for you.
[Beat] Why?
[Beat] Real is overrated.
STARKS smiles back uncertainly.
You don't think that's crazy?
Maybe. [Beat] Maybe not.
She holds up her glass somewhat sadly.
Sometimes I don't know the difference myself. And, you know something? I think I like it better that way. [Finishes her drink] You want another one?
She goes to the KITCHEN, and STARKS clears their PLATES.
STARKS goes in the KITCHEN as she comes out with their drinks. He hears her turn on the RADIO. She lands on an OLDIES station that's playing "Girl of North Country" by Dylan.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, NIGHT

text: STARKS smiles a little, then realizes he remembers, and likes, the song. It's the first familiar thing for him in days. He walks out slowly to the living room, where the WAITRES sits on the couch, drinking. STARKS moves closer to the radio, leaning into it, listening and forgetting, for a s while -- only as long as a piece of song -- everything el
If you go when the snow flakes storm When the rivers freeze and summer ends. Please see she has a coat so warm To keep her from the howlin' winds...
STARKS listens close -- smiling a small, sad smile. Over HARMONICA, we pull back and see two very lonely people passing time together the way people sometimes need to be able to.
This is a great song.
You remember it? STARKS [Nodding slowly] It's like I feel like...I know who I am. I just can't remember anything that made me this person.
When STARKS looks at her then, he's so close to a meltdow that it takes him a moment to fight his way out of it.
But hey, who can forget those words? The man just wants simple and good things for his woman -- that she be warm and happy. How hard can that be to remember?

May be easy to remember, but not easy to get. Being warm, maybe -- but, look, you don't even have a coat and I still have to chop wood to make a fire. [Beat] And, being happy...you tell me if that's simple.
The CHRISTMAS LIGHTS flash drowsily to their own tempo. WAITRESS [re: the lights] Why don't I try to get them to stop blinking?

location: LIVING ROOM, WAITRESS' APARTMENT, AN HOUR OR SO LATE

text: She is visibly drained, after the day and the drinks.
They told me I joined the army when I was seventeen. That's when my father died and, before that, it was apparently just me and him since I was born 'cause my mom split.
So you never knew your mother?
I guess not. But, as of now, I never knew either.
I'm sorry.
Yeah. [Beat] How about you?

Never knew my father. I grew up with my mother. Actually, I grew up around my mother. She was great though. I mean, the way she was with her friends... She was this woman who had so much life in her, she had to find ways to kill some of it just to be like the rest of us. [Beat] She died young.
How?
She fucked herself up day after day and then, one day, she fell asleep with a burning cigarette. [Beat] I came home from work and she was gone.
The TEARS still run after all these years.
I'm sorry.
Yeah, me too. [Softly] Every day for the last ten years.
That when you stopped being a nurse?

She is surprised that he gleaned the connection -- and th been listening so closely. WAITRESS [Exhausted] Yeah, that's when I stopped being a nurse. I never thought I could stop being one, I wanted it for so long, but... you just can't do it anymore when you lose someone like that. You can't take care of other people.
She closes her eyes and finally passes out. STARKS watche her face, lit serenely by the FIRE and the Christmas ligh It bears her grief even in sleep.

He covers her with a BLANKET then looks around and spots only PERSONAL EFFECTS in the room on her mantle. He walks towards them, tripping slightly on a CORD from the LIGHTS stumbles but regains his balance by reaching for the wall As he pulls himself up, he spots what is only inches away from where his hand landed on the wall: HIS OWN DOG TAGS, given to Jackie, only a couple weeks ago, hanging from a single NAIL tacked into the wall. Stunned, he stares at his NAME and BIRTH DATE scored on t metal. He looks back at the WAITRESS and then to the few PICTURES on the mantle: they are of JACKIE and her mother JEAN. STARKS runs his hand through his hair, trying to swallow the improbability, and inexplicability, of the situation. STARKS' EYES search the room for ANYTHING that could help figure out what's happening. On the console is an OLD PAP and some MAIL. Totally disoriented, STARKS nearly STUMBLE his way to the PILE. The label on the first BILL reads "Jackie Price." On the second, the same. And the third...until at the bottom of pile, STARKS spots an OLD NEWSPAPER with the answer on it DATE: December 3, 2004. STARKS is absolutely stunned. STARKS looks over at JACKIE and, just then, the HARSH SOU of the DRAWER being opened rings deafeningly in his ears the image of her starts to DISSOLVE at this worst moment. is being taken out of the JACKET...

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, BASEMENT, ALPINE GROVE, LATE NIGHT

text: It's DR. GRIES, racked with guilt, who pulls Starks out.. He winces at the sight of the BLOOD and SWEAT streaked ac Starks' face. DR. GRIES checks his pulse and cleans his f as best as he can with a WET TOWEL.
William, can you hear me?

His VOICE echoes in the morgue, sounding to Starks, as it does to us, faint and distant. DR. GRIES drips some WATER Starks' mouth. As some of it trickles out, it runs into t JACKET, burning STARKS' chafed skin. STARKS' EYES flutter and DR. GRIES pushes the drawer back afraid of what they've done to this man...
STARKS clenches his face and pleadingly closes his eyes. SECONDS OF TOTAL BLACKNESS and SILENCE and he's back in..

Only now, he's kneeling beside her sleeping FACE, just looking at it. STARKS doesn't know what's going on but he serene, sleeping face steadies him. He can only call out name he thinks she might respond to...
Jackie? Jackie?
Sure enough, she answers with a STIR in her sleep.
Hm...

We see, in STARKS' eyes, the unbelievable connection: she the same little girl he met only a few weeks ago in 1992. STARKS [Swallowing, softly] Jackie? [Beat] What year is it? JACKIE [In a drunken slumber] What?
What year is it? JACKIE [Barely opening her eyes] 2004.
STARKS looks around as JACKIE moves in her sleep, almost falling off the couch. STARKS picks her up and, in her sl she WRAPS her arms around his neck.

head_text.subj: INT. BEDROOM, JACKIE'S APARTMENT, NIGHT

text: STARKS tenderly lays her down on the bed...

head_text.subj: INT. LIVING ROOM, JACKIE'S APARTMENT, NIGHT

text: STARKS picks up his DOG TAGS from the console, looks arou spots the TELEVISION and fumbles a bit as he figures out to turn it on. STARKS sits down, throws back the rest of JACKIE'S DRINK and another shot and looks around nervousl unable to explain what's happening to him...

head_text.subj: INT. BEDROOM, JACKIE'S APARTMENT, CHRISTMAS MORNING

text: JACKIE sits in her sleep as she wakes up, clearly hung ov

head_text.subj: INT. BATHROOM, JACKIE'S APARTMENT, CHRISTMAS MORNING

text: As JACKIE closes the MEDICINE CABINET, she sees her hungo reflection in it. She puts her face under the WATER and lets it restore som color and life in her. As she comes up, that's when she remembers the night before and the voice she barely heard her sleep. STARKS [O.S., echoing distantly] Jackie? [Beat] What year is it?
She SHOOTS UP from the sink, staring at her reflection.

head_text.subj: INT. LIVING ROOM, JACKIE'S APARTMENT, SECONDS LATER

text: JACKIE spots STARKS asleep on the couch -- newspaper stre all around him and the TV still on. He's holding the TAGS She kneels down close to his face and stares at him for awhile before STARKS is jarred. He defensively GRABS HER WRIST as his EYES BURST OPEN, startling her. JACKIE [Desperately] Who are you?
STARKS lets his GRIP loosen.
[Beat] I'm William Starks.
A short look of SHOCK cross her face before she leaps up.
Get the hell out of my house!
JACKIE grabs the nearest object -- the IRON FORK from the FIREPLACE set -- and holds it, shaking, against STARKS. S stays calm; he hardly expected a different reaction.
What'd you do? Snoop all over the place? You had no right. You had no right to go through anything.
[Beat] I know it doesn't make sense. It doesn't even make sense to me.

If you don't get out of my house right now, I'll call the police. STARKS [Remembering] Your mom was passed out on the side of the road when I found you. Her name was Jean. [Beat] She was dizzy the whole time... JACKIE [Trembling] Why would you do something like this? I tried to help you.
Jackie, I'm William Starks. I can prove it.
What? Now you're gonna show me some kind of driver's license?
No, I don't have anything to show you. I'm here from a mental hospital.
Well, you belong in one. STARKS [Solemnly] [Beat] You and your mom were in a truck and she kept a rifle in the back of it...
Stop it! Stop it!
JACKIE covers her ears and looks at him, pleading with he eyes. STARKS' eyes plead right back.
I'm sorry for upsetting you, [beat] but I'm not lying to you.
You can't be William Starks. He's dead.
[Beat] What?
William Starks is dead... [Beat] I've been to his grave.
[Beat] What?
His body was found New Year's Day, 19...1993. At Alpine... STARKS [Finishing for her] Alpine Grove. That's the mental hospital. How do you know that?
I looked it up.
How?
Then he remembers -- understanding with a chill that what is saying could entirely be true.
I gave you my dog tags.
No, you didn't. They found William Starks' body dead in the snow.
How'd he die?
I don't know. But he did die.

STARKS falters under the news. JACKIE looks around, throu her now blurred eyes, like she might find some help in th apartment. She settles for the BOTTLE of VODKA on the tab lowers the iron fork and takes a long heavy drink, then laughs nervously as she looks up.

I know what this is...I picked you up when I was drunk and you probably thought I'm just fucked up enough to fall for this. But the thing is I know what I'm doing when I drink. I just usually don't care. Right now, I do though. And I want you out. Now.
It's December 25th, 1993 today.
No, it's not. [Beat] It's December 25th, 2004. STARKS [Desperate] That can't be. That's...just, I mean... You're telling me I died in less than a week in the time I'm in.

I'm telling you I don't care what time you think you're in. You're not William Starks. [Beat] I don't believe in many things, but I believe in death. And it doesn't give back what it takes. So whoever you are...I did a nice thing, you've made me regret it enough already, so please, just leave.

I'll leave. But look at me. Look at my face, Jackie. I'm not lying. I met you and your mother. I told you then that I'd lost my memory. [Beat] There was no one for miles around so I know you know there's no way I could have known that from a pair of dog tags you had lying around.
Please...
STARKS looks at her tenderly before he turns to leave. JACKIE, a little calmer, looks at the door like he's stil the other side of it and calls out softly, and sadly...
Happy Birthday.

STARKS looks around him and, we see, from bottom up, the exterior around Jackie's house melt away as STARKS sudden faces the massacred village in Iraq. Shocked at what's happening to his body, he looks up, petrified. His body i wound as tightly as a knot.

Again, we're glimpsing the scene through PHOSPHORESCENT G NIGHT VISION intermittently negotiated with real-time ima Opposite Starks stands a CRAZED IRAQI SOLDIER -- seething anger and pointing his gun at a LITTLE BOY, presumably belonging to the MAN not five feet away. Next to Starks i angry CAPTAIN MEDLEY, ordering STARKS to follow him. STAR is watching himself in the scene.
You walk on. They pick up their guns and fire at you, you stay. They pick up and fire at each other, and you walk on!
He's got his gun pointed at a kid.
That is not our problem.
Yeah, well, none of this is our fuckin' problem.
STARKS turns and aims his gun at a CRAZED IRAQI SOLDIER threatening to shoot a child. We hear him YELLING in Arab What STARKS doesn't see is another IRAQI SOLDIER (2) aimi his GUN at STARKS.
We are leaving this site right now.
STARKS doesn't hear him; he's busy perfecting his aim. STARKS [To the first Iraqi soldier] Hey!

At the force of the word, the SOLDIER lowers his gun and LITTLE BOY flees. STARKS, who is now in the scene himself, lowers his gun slightly as he approaches the SOLDIER. Neither speaks the other's language but they're both saying everything with their eyes. Neither moves his off the other. Just then, though, we see the SECOND IRAQI SOLDIER get a clear aim at STARKS.

He takes his SHOT before anyone else does. STARKS goes do as the skin off the side of his head is shaved off. He falls to the ground. As the rest of the picture fades black, all that is left is previously mysterious, still haunting PAIR of EYES that we now see belonged to the CRAZED IRAQI SOLDIER. And over it all is the now more distant CLANK OF METAL as drawer is opened and the nightmare momentarily ended...

head_text.subj: INT. MORGUE, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS DAY

text: DR. GRIES, DR. BECKER, DAMON and NURSE HARDING enter the room.
You left him in all night?
Shit, he's probably dead. DR. GRIES [Defensively] I tried to ask you if we should leave him in yesterday...
Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. [Beat] Just open the drawer.
We never should have done this to him...
Well, what are we gonna do about it now?
Nothing is Gries' answer. Still, Becker seems to share th concern. BECKER motions for them to open the drawer. They pull him out. STARKS looks cold and wrecked.
Is he? [Impatiently] Is he dead?
BECKER feels for a pulse and seems surprised to find one.
No. [To Harding and Damon] Get him upstairs.

head_text.subj: INT. WARD, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS DAY

text: DR. LORENSON walks into the ward to check on STARKS. The attending NURSE is walking around the ward.
Where's William Starks.
I'm not sure. Dr. Becker had him moved.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: DR. LORENSON walks anxiously down the halls of the hospit peering into every room, looking for Starks.

head_text.subj: INT. ANOTHER HALLWAY, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: DR. LORENSON spots BECKER walking out the DOORS of the hospital and RUNS after him, in only his white coat...

head_text.subj: EXT. PARKING LOT, ALPINE GROVE, DAY, (CONT'D)

text: LORENSON [Calling out after him] Dr. Becker! Dr. Becker!...Tom, wait!
DR. BECKER stops walking and waits a moment, registering voice, before he turns around to face Dr. Lorenson. LORENSON [Out of breath] Where's William Starks?
He's recovering on the third floor.
Are you kidding me? He's not psychotic!
Then how would you describe him, Beth? Merely rebellious?
He'll be a zombie in a few days, Tom. His behavior's hardly suggested he needed neuroleptics.
And you know that from what, a couple two-minute stares across a room? LORENSON [Firmly] He didn't need anti-psychotics, if that's even all you're giving him...?

BECKER ignores Lorenson's insinuation and merely turns hi CHEEK all the way round towards Lorenson so he can see th BANDAGE from the CUT Starks gave him. BECKER [Steadily] After he slashed me with a hospital instrument, I determined, in my professional opinion, that Mr. Starks, needed a little placating.
[Beat] You sure he wasn't provoked?
You sure you want to begin making that kind of insinuation? [Beat] I took five stitches during a routine therapy session.

I'm sure he took some, too. BECKER [Smirking, unphased] Happens sometimes when you've got to restrain them. You watch the rest of us work. You know that. LORENSON [Appealing to him] Our patients are sick.
Yes, they are.
LORENSON looks at BECKER; he knows he's hiding something.

He's not gonna end up like Casey, Tom. Whatever happened to him is not going to "happen" to Starks. I don't know what you're trying to do here ...but he's not a lab animal, Tom. You can't reprogram him no matter the drugs or the treatment.
Jesus, you really don't let up, do you? Just because you failed your patient doesn't necessarily mean the rest of us did, too. [Beat] Sorry to tarnish your war hero's image, but he is psychotic.
LORENSON looks back, starting to grasp Becker's misshapen beliefs.
Now, if you'll excuse me, it's Christmas, and I have a family I'd like to see.

location: ROOM, INTENSIVE CARE UNIT, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS D

text: STARKS, IV in arm, lies asleep in bed, recovering...
JACKIE walks in a hospital -- with many aspects parallel the mental hospital. White on white and, for Jackie particularly, the presence of painful memories.

location: ROOM, INTENSIVE CARE UNIT, ALPINE GROVE, CHRISTMAS D

text: LORENSON walks closer to STARKS and carefully examines th BRUISES and BURNS on a body that's been badly beaten. His eyes bear his guilt.
JACKIE waits until a nurse, CLAIRE, greets her perfunctor CLAIRE [Not looking up] How can I help you?
Hi, Claire.
CLAIRE looks up, astonished to see her. She smiles warmly
Jackie, hi. How are you, honey?
I'm ok. [Beat] I need a favor.

STARKS is asleep when a DARK FIGURE walks, like a GHOST, the WINDOWED DOOR of his room. STARKS opens his eyes and snaps his neck in its direction -- fearful of everything this point. When he looks, there's nothing there; he's no sure there ever was. The room starts to blue as he looks around it, not knowing if he is crazy...

JACKIE peruses HEADLINES and ABSTRACTS pulled up on the w "ALPINE GROVE INVESTIGATION into the mysterious death of William Starks..." "The body of WILLIAM STARKS, the former war hero who was charged with the murder of OFFICER EDWARD HARRISON, was found on the grounds of ALPINE GROVE on January 1, 1993. STARKS was believed to have died from a wound to the head."

The words and PHRASES that confirm Starks' story RISE fro their couched places on the computer screen. "Local Doctor charged with medical malpractice." "Dr. Thomas Becker resigns..." "It involved the recreation of a womb-like environment." "Former patients testify to being put in instrument known as the 'Jacket'"... "Patient Rudy MacKenzie testifies..." "WILLIAM STARKS, laurelled war hero..."

As JACKIE keeps scrolling, her face wears her disbelief t what STARKS was saying may have been true. Then, she sees archived in a state newspaper, a mention of Dr. Lorenson a particular patient, "Eugene Yazdi." "Local Boy, Eugene Yazdi, Overcomes Absence Seizure Syndrome to Win Mathematic Decathlon...with the aid of Local Doctor, Dr. Loel Lorenson." "Panelists for National Epilepsy Conference include Dr. Lorenson, Alpine Grove Hospital."
A NURSE is checking on STARKS as he slowly wakes up.
What the hell kind of drugs are you people giving me?
STARKS is asking the NURSE, but it's BECKER's voice that answers though Starks can't see him.
Just something to help you sleep.

STARKS panics when he hears the voice. He looks around nervously but the BRIGHT SUNLIGHT pouring into the room i blinding. He swallows as he looks at the NURSE'S FACE as continues adjusting his pillows. STARKS [Swallowing nervously] Did you say something?
The NURSE shakes her head lightly and just then BECKER st out of the LIGHT.
I said the drugs were to help you sleep. [Beat] Did you sleep well?
Becker is remarkably calm, further confusing Starks' sens reality. STARKS [Doubtfully] But I wasn't asleep. Was I?
Yes. You were. You were asleep for nearly a whole day. It's December 26th, William.
STARKS sits up groggily, remembering what happened to him wondering how much, if any of it, was real.
It's December 26th?
STARKS examines himself -- looking at his arms, spotting BRUISES on them.
That's right, William. STARKS [Slowly figuring it out] 1992?
BECKER nods. STARKS sits up -- his predicament and the ro slowly coming into focus.
Yes. [Caustically] And that's the sun and you're on earth. [Beat] And I know you know better.
STARKS begins to piece if together. BECKER, as we begin t see, is right. It is 1992 in Alpine Grove.
I don't know better. All I know is that you left me in there.
In where?
[Uncertainly] In that thing...the Jacket.
The NURSE gives Becker a knowing look -- suggesting Stark really is delusional. Becker doesn't even flinch as STARK tries to get a better look at Becker's face.
We were forced to use restrains if that's what you're referring to.
That wasn't a fucking restraint.
Actually, that's exactly what our equipment is.

STARKS' EYES widen with alarm as BECKER reaches for the I in his arm, lingering on it long enough that Starks brace himself for an ATTACK of some sort. But Becker just looks back innocently as he adjusts it.
Relax.
Don't act like I don't know what's real. [Beat] I'm not the one that's crazy here.
[Pointedly] Of course you're not.
Then he clarifies, wryly enough for Starks to catch it.
You're just suffering from delusions that are unfortunately part of your condition.
Don't give me that. I know what's real, goddamnit! You strapped me in something and stuck me in a drawer.
BECKER nods diagnostically. The NURSE's nonchalance about as she LEAVES the room further disquiets STARKS.
I didn't dream it. I may have been asleep but it wasn't a dream.
BECKER sits down in a CHAIR, half-shrouded in the light.
I had a patient a few years ago. His name was Ted Casey...
I don't give a shit about your patient!
I wasn't pausing to see if you did. [Beat] But, incidentally, you should, because you're birds of a feather.
STARKS squints as he searches out Becker's face.

Ted raped and sodomized a seven-year old girl. [Beat] His lawyers asked me to have a look at him because, after his deeds were done... he climbed into the trees of the forest where he killed her and woofed like a dog. He couldn't even remember his name when I spoke to him, but, curiously enough, he could speak back. [Beat] Ted never went to prison because everyone -- including me -- was convinced he was sick. So he came here.
BECKER leans into Starks' view to make sure he's listenin STARKS is.

Then one day a little girl came with her mother to visit a relative and I caught Ted stealing looks at her -- the kind you really have to steal if you know what I mean. [Beat] I asked Ted then if he could remember what the little girl who he had... slain ...was wearing. [Beat] He gave me a look I'll never forget, and, when he answered, it wasn't with a color or any sort of physical description I'd expect. "Oh yes," he said. "I remember it. I remember it well." [Beat] Those were actually his last words I think.
BECKER's expression bears a hunting mixture of anger and remorse as he recounts Ted's tale.
We are not birds of a feather.
Maybe not. [Beat] But I do think you're in a tree... woofing like a dog. And I'm just trying to help you the only way I can think of.
BECKER gets up and, as he moves out of the light, STARKS his BANDAGED CHEEK, reinforcing his memory of what happened... STARKS [Provokingly] What happened to your cheek, Dr. Becker?
I was careless. Happens sometimes.

location: STARKS' ROOM, RECOVERY WARD, ALPINE GROVE, DAY, 1992

text: STARKS looks out on the SNOW-COVERED GROUNDS from his roo the third floor. He seems pacified for the moment.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, RECOVERY WARD, ALPINE GROVE, DAY

text: Everything about the dingy hospital punctuates the sad mechanics of managing madness. CATATONIC PATIENTS and dat equipment litter the hall and, as we follow a NURSE who w among them, we spot STARKS -- ARMS suspended in air and G EYES fixed on the ceiling -- pretending to be one of them
His ARMS fall and he wipes his dried MOUTH as soon as she passes. STARKS has successfully made it out of his room. turns one corner as STARKS hustles to turn another...

STARKS is almost   there. As RANDOM ORDERLIES pass him, S lets his posture   collapse as he despondently hangs his down so low they   can't see his face. They pass, and STA starts scuttling   towards the door to the outside. As soon as he reaches it and is outside in the cold -- wi only his BLUE PATIENT UNIFORM -- Starks walks normally, l he no longer remembers the risks. Instead he remembers wh Jackie told him.
They found William Starks' body dead in the snow.
How'd he die?
I don't know. But he did die.

STARKS leans down -- seemingly oblivious to the cold -- a lifts some snow to his mouth, TASTING it like a man who n to affirm he is still alive. He's so rapt that LORENSON's VOICE takes him by surprise.
Hey. You're not supposed to be out here.

STARKS stiffens as he realizes he could be in the place w his body was found. The terrible question asks itself on face: Is this when Starks is killed? STARKS [Turning around sharply] What are you going to do to me?
Well...
As LORENSON reaches into his POCKET for something, STARKS anxiously holds his breath. It's BLACK when it comes out a SKI HAT when it opens up. STARKS lets out his breath, relieved.
LORENSON [Nonchalantly] I thought I'd just ask you to come back inside with me.
And if I didn't want to come?
I guess I'd ask you why.
Because I don't think I'm crazy.
You're not crazy.
STARKS is surprised by Lorenson's agreement.

You suffer from delusional disorder. That doesn't mean you're... crazy. It just means you're confused. And you're here, instead of in jail, because that was determined to have played a role in your killing of a police officer. STARKS [Correcting him] Alleged killing of a police officer.
You were convicted of the crime.
That conviction doesn't convince me of anything. Until I know that I did it, I'm not going to accept that I did.
You may never remember at all. [Beat] Your mind's grasp of reality and the real events that have happened to you has been damaged.
No. The real events that have happened to me have been fucked up. Not my mind.
LORENSON seems to realize -- at least for an instant -- t is looking at a desperate man who is persuasively, and cogently, staring back at him.
[Beat] William, I'd like to ask you something if I can.
Since when do people around here have to ask permission to do anything? LORENSON [Suspiciously] How's your treatment progressing with Dr. Becker?
STARKS still doesn't know how much Lorenson knows, and if should trust him.
Fine. [Beat] Why made you ask?
LORENSON answers first with his eyes looking over Starks' body. STARKS merely stares back tersely. LORENSON [Carefully] I just hope you'd let me know if that wasn't the case.
Why, what would you do?
I could try to...make it stop.
No. I don't want it to.
So it's helping? STARKS [Choosing his words carefully] [Beat] It's making me feel like a different person.

LORENSON -- sensing she's not going to get any more from Starks -- turns around to go back inside. It's only as sh turns her face away from STARKS that we see how nervous s is. But you'd never guess it from her tone... LORENSON [Casually] You comin'?
STARKS looks towards the FENCES locking him in from every direction. LORENSON waits until she hears STARKS' FOOTSTE following her. She waits until STARKS has reached her.
You should be careful. You could be killed if they found you out here.
Believe me, I know.
STARKS and MACKENZIE are eating opposite each other.
What were you talking about the other day?
I wasn't talking about anything.
Yeah, you were. What you said about them taking me out to the woods...
MACKENZIE clams up slightly at the mention of it...
What do you know about the Jacket?
MACKENZIE's eyes start to twitch nervously.
I know you need one when it's really cold.
[Cutting in] MacKenzie, listen to me. Listen. I'm going to die.
Mortality's actually a great thing to be familiar with. It means you're sane on some level.
[Gravely] No, I mean in four days, I'm supposed to die.
[Beat] How do you know?
The Jacket.
MACKENZIE grows visibly more nervous at this second menti of it.
Oh no, you're pretty young. Your body'll be able to handle a lot more of it than you think...
No. [Beat] I mean I found out while I was in it that my body's gonna be found in four days.
Just then, NURSE HARDING is upon them. She carries a ROD her hand which she TAPS menacingly on the floor as she wa towards them.
What are you two yappin' about?

STARKS tenses up as he sees only the ROD, which could inf a GASH if hit across a man's head the right way. Nearly e object could be a threat to his life as this point. MACKENZIE [Spoken like a nut] [Beat] We're talking about our ability to go forward in time, to go into the future. [To Starks] That is what we're talking about here, right?
STARKS is startled MacKenzie gets it.
Yeah, it is.
You know something? You're two fucking freaks is what you are. STARKS [Smiling] Well, no shit, Einstein. What do you think we're doing in this place?
MACKENZIE tries not to laugh but a CHUCKLE slips out.
I want the two of you to shut the fuck up and eat your food.
HARDING walks away with a final stare that Starks returns STARKS [Under his breath] I gotta get back in it, MacKenzie.
It's gonna be sticky.
Why?
MACKENZIE's body betrays his discomfort talking about it its sudden jerks accompanying every word.
'Cause Lorenson's got her claws in it now. When she started getting suspicious about me was when they stopped using it on me. Women!
So what am I supposed to do?

You could still always give Becker an itch. 'Course you might get killed when he goes to scratch it, but seems to me you're saying that's about to happen anyway. [Beat] Just be careful not to walk yourself right into something.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY, ALPINE GROVE, 1992, DAY

text: Dr. LORENSON and DR. GRIES are walking briskly to a meeti
We're late.
I wish they'd skip the formality of this annual review and just cut our budget. Our silence on the matter should be enough to appease the civic conscience without wasting an hour we don't have.
Maybe it's not such a waste.
LORENSON looks at GRIES askance before she sets the recor straight.
It's the ticking of a box on a sheet of paper no one cares about.
They don't care about all the things we do right. [Beat] But they might ...they might care about what we're doing wrong. [Beat] That's what they should come here to look for.
LORENSON can see GRIES is trying to tell her something.
What should they be looking for?
They should just be looking harder.
LORENSON grabs GRIES' arm, sensing the import of her word
Where? [Beat] It's Becker isn't it? He's doing stuff, isn't he?
Later. I'll tell you about it later. We got a session to catch now.

head_text.subj: INT. WARD 3, ALPINE GROVE, 1992, DAY

text: STARKS is in a different ward with PATIENTS who appear mo threatening and disturbed. As he is anxiously looking aro presumably for a way out -- Starks hears one of the PATIE humming an eerily DISCORDANT MELODY. Looking to see who i comes from, STARKS happens to spot ONE PATIENT -- a young fierce-looking guy -- eyeing a YOUNG NURSE, SALLY, administering medication from a dated CART. STARKS looks around the room and notes there are NO DOCTO or ORDERLIES around. The YOUNG NURSE, meanwhile, is focus on the medicine -- oblivious to the BRUTE eyeing her. The BRUTE's not that far away when he starts walking towa the YOUNG NURSE. STARKS starts in their direction, pickin speed -- maneuvering through VARIOUS INCOHERENT PATIENTS the BRUTE reaches the NURSE. He throws her TRAY down and pushes her against the WALL. starts screaming as he pushes up against her. STARKS pick the TRAY and strikes the BRUTE across the head with it. The BRUTE holds his head in pain as he tries to regain hi balance. It's clear he's impaired. But it's also clear he understands pain.
STARKS [To Sally] You ok?

As she NODS, her EYES dart above to the HAND about to str him. Off her look, he ducks and turns around, punching th BRUTE in the stomach -- HARD -- but not before the piece he held from one of the broken MEDICINE BOTTLES comes perilously close to STARKS' head. The BRUTE bowls over and STARKS looks at the GLASS terrif Is this when he dies? The BRUTE -- incensed more than ever -- lunges at him a f STARKS gets him by the NECK, expertly applying PRESSURE POINTS and, after only a few seconds, subdues him. STARKS himself seems surprised that he knew how to use them. He out a suspended BREATH, instinctively touching his FOREHE to make sure he's not cut. He looks back at SALLY.
Are you ok?
Yeah, Why are you in this ward alone? Where is everyone? SALLY [Defensively] There's a state rep visiting so they've moved everyone around. But I've been alone before...
Where are the other orderlies?
In the therapy session downstairs. That's what the rep's sitting in on...
Ok, listen. I want you to get out of here and lock the door behind you. I'll go get some doctors.
SALLY looks at STARKS, wondering whether she can trust hi Her eyes shift to the BRUTE on the floor and she remember that she can.

location: MAIN ROOM, WARD, ALPINE GROVE, DAY, 1992

text: The STATE REP -- 40s, disgruntled, even drowsy -- is recognizable among a group that includes the CHIEF OF STA (Dr. Williams), BECKER, LORENSON and GRIES. They are presiding over a GROUP THERAPY SESSION when STARKS enters STARKS [Calling out] Sorry I'm late, Dr. Becker.
BECKER is noticeably taken aback but tempers his response
Mr. Starks, this session is for our civil patients. Damon, please take Mr. Starks back to his ward.

STARKS cuts him off and threatens with his gaze. STARKS [Derisively] No. Please, Dr. Becker. You can strap me in a Jacket or even gag me, but please don't leave me out of therapy. This is where I feel like I make the most progress.
BECKER relents, seeing STARKS has the upper hand -- an AUDIENCE, deranged but eager no less.
Fine, Mr. Starks. You can pull up a chair for yourself.

As STARKS walks across the room, it's obvious to everyone they turn their heads to watch him -- that he is a physic ailing man. Using all his strength, he walks up slowly to group, dragging a CHAIR behind him because he doesn't hav the strength to lift it. STARKS sits down.
Mr. Jensen, please continue.
JENSEN -- a twitchy schizophrenic -- surveys the group seriously, determining whether it's safe to say what he's about to...
Well, [beat] I've been approached by the Federal Trade Organization.
BECKER's not listening to a word JENSEN says. But STARKS
BECKER [Calm as ever] And what have they approached you about, Mr. Jensen?
They want me to head the Organization for the Organized.
The other PATIENTS look at him in wonder as the STATE REP listens limply.
The Organization...for the Organized?
That's right. Have you heard of them?
No, Mr. Jensen. I have not.
That's because there is no such Organization, you idiot.

That is categorically not true. Bl-bl- blatantly and manifestly NOT TRUE. I've been asked to lead them. But, if you'd heard of them, then they wouldn't be hush-hush, would they? BECKER [Wearily] What do the rest of you think?
The GROUP stares at one another silently. STARKS [Loud and emphatic] Well, [beat] I know they exist.
And how is that?
STARKS looks at JENSEN, who looks back avidly. MACKENZIE Starks nervously, like he senses what he is about to do.
When I was in the Gulf, the Organization was recruiting the Organized.
BECKER [Incensed] Is that a fact, Mr. Starks? Because if it's not, it doesn't help Mr. Jensen. STARKS [Looking right at Jensen] It is a fact. Bona fide, and classified.
LORENSON and MACKENZIE watch STARKS curiously.
I knew it! I knew it! Those little fuckers are everywhere.
They recruit only the best, Mr. Jensen. [Beat] I didn't want to have to say this...
Not even the DOCTORS dare disrupt the silence...

But these people [pointing to the Doctors] know about it. In fact, when Presidents of this country and heads of state leave office, they come here, to Alpine Grove. They're among us right now! [Looking right at Becker] Isn't that right, Dr. Thatcher? And Jensen, I'm proud they picked you.
JENSEN looks on nobly.
They're always ordering us to stay calm, but how can we be calm?
STARKS suddenly turns right at Becker, wrapping his messa to him in the seemingly crazed theatrics of a nut.
[Looking suddenly directly at Becker] All they do is give orders. That's all they have to do. And no one will ever know. All it comes down to is an order. [Beat] They've got hands everywhere.
STARKS stands up, ready to SALUTE Mr. Jensen. The OBSERVE look to BECKER for order.
Long live the Organization for the Organized!
Sit down, Mr. Starks! Sit down, Mr. Starks!
